==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|s=为|t2=爲}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etyl}}
{{Han simp|爲|f=爫|t=丶}}. In the oracle bone script, it is an {{Han compound|又|t1=hand|象|t2=elephant|ls=ic}} — a hand holding an animal (an elephant or a monkey). The {{zh-l|*又}} later became {{zh-l|*爪|hand; claw}}. ''{{w|Shuowen Jiezi}}'' explained the character to be a representation of the female macaque.

===Etymology===
The two pronunciations below (“to make; to do; to be”, “for; to; because”) are cognate; the latter is the *''–s'' derivative of the former. Words meaning “to make, to do” often have secondary meanings of “for, as” – compare {{zh-m|*作}}.

Etymology not certain. {{zh-ref|Starostin}} compared this word with {{cog|bo|བགྱིད||to make, to manufacture}}, {{m|bo|བགྱི་བ||action, deed}}, {{m|bo|ཡིན||is, be}} and {{cog|my|ဝေ||to distribute, to share}}. {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} listed {{m|mkh-pro|*ʔaayh||to give}} (> {{cog|km|ឲ្យ||to give, to donate}}) and {{cog|km|ធ្វើ||to do, to make}}, although the vowels do not match.

The graphic representation using monkey or elephant probably stems a homophonic or near-homophonic etymon which was rarely attested; compare {{cog|sit-pro|*b/g-woj-n}} > {{cog|kac|woi||monkey}} and possibly {{och-l|猿|ape}}. Outside Sino-Tibetan, compare {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*-vɔːj||elephant}} > {{cog|vi|voi||elephant}}.
